segments.Text:
This text was transcribed using whisper model: large-v2

 Thank you very much. Thanks for coming out. I want to talk a little bit about security
operations and basically a survey that I've written for the last seven years in terms
of studying of what people are doing for security operations. So just a little bit about me
and why you might be interested in hearing my opinions and thoughts on people running
cyber security operations. I work as a consultant and people typically call the style of consulting
that I do like an army of one. I basically have zero employees. I do all my own contracting.
I do all my own engagements. I actually do my delivery. Yes, his eyes are popping like
why the hell would you do that to yourself? It is a little bit strange, but it works for
me. I've been working in security operations for a while. Basically, I wrote a class on
this. I've been writing the survey. I started working in computers when I was 15 years old
and that's in the 80s. So I was doing Unix systems administration, running tape in high
school, that kind of stuff. I've been teaching for the SANS Institute and I've been a certified
SANS instructor for more than 10 years. I've worked in US government quite a bit, defense
energy, non-defense, non-energy agencies. I've worked for a number of different organizations
across a number of different sectors. What I've tried to do over the last several years
is really get my knowledge and my understanding of the way that things work, my anecdotal
experience with the way that things work into a more generalized construct of how people
actually do cybersecurity operations. If you want to connect on LinkedIn or Twitter,
I'm never on either of those, but if you send me a message there, I'll answer it in a couple
of weeks. I have sort of this problem with running a SOC survey because all of the surveys
that we see all the time, it's just somebody's opinion to a question that they're not really
data to us. So with that in mind, if I say data, please refactor that in your brain. It's not data.
I've not been like measuring things. This is not mass. I'm not going into other people's
SOCs and actually looking at the detections that they've engineered in order to be able
to comprehend it. That being said, this is probably the most open source of insight into
other people's cybersecurity operations that you will find. And I've worked really hard
to try to collect information in a way, collect responses in a way that I can then share that
with people in order to do something useful with it. Because in my experience, a lot of
people will say, okay, well, we're running our SOC this way. What is that company doing?
What is that organization doing? How can I do it like them? And people are constantly
holding their cards really close to themselves and then trying to peek at other people's hands
to see what they're doing. And so I'm trying to facilitate that in a way that provides some
sort of a third party that's somewhat trusted. So if you do work in a SOC, if you do work as
an analyst, if you have engineered or architected a SOC, I would appreciate it if either this year
or next year you actually respond to the survey. Also, there's a release event that's coming up
for the 24 survey that you can get to. I'm talking about the data from the previous one
and the response period is open currently for the current one, which will be released in,
I don't know, it's like July or August or something like that. Okay. This website,
soc-survey.com also has links to the last seven years of reports. And since 2020, I've released
the data, de-identified of course, which is something that I think is pretty important,
so that people can look at how I'm doing the analysis and point out and say, no, no, no,
you did that wrong. Like that's completely wrong. And I'll get into some of that in a little bit.
So let me talk about some of the highlights of the 23 survey in order to just explain what I'm
seeing. Some of this stuff, you're going to see a chart and it's just like, okay, this is what
the answers are. And then some of what I say is actually going to be Chris's opinion on why that
comes out that way and what people are actually doing. So an interesting thing about the survey
is that roughly 640 people took it and the average time, and the survey is done in Qualtrics,
the average time to take the survey was 59 minutes. Excuse me, the mean time was 59 minutes.
59 minutes where somebody sat there and took a survey. They didn't get paid for it and they spent
an hour doing it. Now this is an interesting thing in and of itself. The people who are
answering this are actually investing a lot of time in it. And just in talking to people about
this, something that people have told me, just taking the survey challenges them to think about
how they're doing their operations. And the other thing is, this suggests to me that it's
quality responses. I mean, this is not a five-minute thing that people are just like,
where's my $50 gift card at the end of it? Because there is no gift card at the end of it,
right? So this is another reason why this is actually something that's useful. I think that
you could take this and then people have told me they take it and get budget based on, hey,
this is what they're saying is useful in our environment. Another thing that's quite useful
is a technology comparison. And I'll get to some technology explanations later where your peers
have graded in the survey what technologies work for them, what technologies don't work for them,
what technologies they're able to get into production fully, partially, or not at all.
So if you go look at this and you're like, hey, I want to buy this great new deception capability,
generally around deception, your peers don't like it and they can't get it fully into production.
So if you still want it, you might be thinking, okay, how do I constrain my deployment so that
I'm only tactically deploying it into some specific place to make sure that it does exactly what I
want rather than thinking about doing deception generally across my entire enterprise? Okay,
so that might be a useful thing that you can do with some of this information.
The other part of this is that this is primarily North American companies and primarily small
companies. I mean, there were some large companies, like if you look at this graphic here,
each of these buildings accounts for basically 25 respondents. So it's something where roughly 80
organizations were larger than 50,000 employees who responded to this. Different roles.
In the last couple of years, we've actually experimented with doing the survey in different
languages. And just as an example, when we did it in Spanish and Portuguese, the respondents actually
shifted to South America instead of Europe as the second group for headquarters. I basically just
haven't been able to keep the funding going to get that into different languages. I've tried to
compel them to do Arabic as just an example. I don't know if you all are aware of this,
but the Middle East is going through a tremendous growth spurt and cyber is part of that. So just
something to think about. If you're in sort of this area, it's not just North America. There are
a lot of people in different places trying to do cybersecurity operations. And in my experience,
they tend to do it somewhat differently depending upon the way that their organizations are
structured. In terms of running a SOC, I asked the question, what do you do? What are your
capabilities? How do you consider whether it is a SOC or not? And so the top things were alerting
and triage. I mean, that seems self-evident, but in fact, that's what the responses sort of confirmed.
The incident response capability was part of the SOC capability. Some organizations will split
that out and say, no, no, our incident responders are over there. This is our monitoring capability.
Compliance and data protection sort of round out the list of the different things that are there.
I'll talk about outsourcing in a moment, but actually this particular representation is
intended to depict in addition to what do you do, how do you do it? What sort of things were
outsourced as opposed to done internally and what things are you actually doing
both internally and outsourced? And I'll come back to some of those aspects of the outsourcing.
For the people who responded to the survey, they said that most of their incidents, they're
actually able to detect prior to having a third-party notification. And this is an interesting
one because when you look at Verizon Data Breach Investigation Report, a lot of what they're
saying is that the breaches tend to be known when you have third-party detection and then you're
being told about that. So the information represented in the respondents to the survey,
most of what they're seeing, they're detecting internally. I can't necessarily say that that is
something that's due to their own maturity or that the people who are self-selecting into the
responses are actually doing this, but this is something that is different than what I've seen
in a bunch of the other industry reports that are out there. Metrics, it's interesting to me
every year when I see this, 84% say that they collect and expose metrics. And every time I see
that answer, I think, what are these other 16% of the people doing? Literally, how does your
organization continue to give you money to run a SOC if you're not reporting anything? I mean,
that seems crazy to me. 11% of them said, no, we don't provide metrics. The other roughly 5%
say that they don't know. So the respondents said that they weren't sure if they were reporting
metrics or not. Of the metrics that are reported, and there's lots of questions around these
different ones, the top three, top one, quantity of incidents, which I think is a meaningless metric,
to be perfectly honest with you. How many did you have? We had 36 last month. Is that the right
number? Is that a good number? Is that going up? Is that going down? The metric itself is something
that is not meaningful, and you're measuring something that is out of your control in terms of
your detective capability. So this is one, though, that a lot of people report that they do.
Time to detect, time from detection to eradication is another one that is frequently
reported. I think that this is actually at least something that you can control for that.
And then the ratio of incidents from known and unknown vulnerabilities, also an interesting thing
that starts to get into posture management capability, vulnerability management, your ability
to actually detect things that are in your environment and then trace that through a root
cause to be able to identify, yeah, this was a problem that we knew about and it hurt us.
So this is something that is quite useful for SOCs to do, and a lot of organizations
don't do it well. And the top metric being the one that's just like a simple count is an indication
of that, in my opinion. The other thing that I asked about was the idea of orchestration automation.
This has become a bit of a buzzword over the last five years. Orchestration automation really is
scripting the tools in order to do the things that work within a workflow that you have decided
is the right way that your organization will run your security operations. So in addition to the
question of are you doing this, there was a question about how do you approach the tuning
needs of the SOAR, which I think is a little bit more insightful rather than are you using it, do
you have this technology, do you like the technology, it's how do you tune it. And what was interesting
to me is the top response is that yes, we do actually frequently change our workflows, and
I'll zoom in on this so maybe you can read it if you want to see it. So we frequently change the
SOAR workflows. We have dedicated staff is actually a lower answer than we frequently change the
workflows and the analysts or users of the SOAR are authorized and empowered to make the change
directly. Now optimally, I think that there would actually be some sort of a workflow verification
prior to an analyst who's in the midst of doing something being authorized to change the workflow.
That being said, the fact that they say that they frequently change it and adjust it anyway, I think
is actually a really positive thing. SOAR is effectively just APIs to be able to pull data
from different places and scripting to do the things that you need to do. So if your analysts
are empowered to do the adjustment on the fly, you're going to have low maturity, but you are
going to be flexible and adaptable. So this is something that I have seen organizations do
moderately well, and I'm happy that people are embracing this. The other thing I will say
about SOAR, again just my opinion on the deployment of this, is while I actually really
prefer the idea of do-it-yourself, write the scripts, do all these things, I think from an
organizational perspective, that is a path of pain in order to decide no, no, no, we're just going to
do all that in Python ourselves. And I think that from an institutional enterprise perspective,
deciding on the best SOAR that matches your requirements and then doing small amounts of
customization is actually the more efficient path. And from somebody who is a control freak,
I want to write the code myself, I want to verify that it's been something that we vetted and did,
I still think from an institutional perspective, the better way is to put it into a tool
that allows you to do that customization and flexibility when you really need it,
but that you don't have to always worry about having a scripting or a programmer on staff
who's competent to be able to make those changes. Another thing that I asked about was the
idea of how do you deal with data? If you're going to do detections, you need to be able to
pull data into some sort of a correlation engine, typically a SIEM. And so what I've found is that
a lot of people just push everything into the SIEM and don't really apply much selection,
and this plays out in the survey responses. Everything goes into the SIEM was the top,
and then there's sort of a risk-based criteria is the next one. And I mean, think about it,
when you are deciding, do you need that data in your SIEM? The easy answer is yes,
right? I'm just going to push it in there in case that we need it. And this is, you know,
if you're sort of a maximalist, you know, packer or camper or whatever you want to say in terms of
how you personally approach things, are you always thinking about being completely minimal
in terms of what information you have on hand? And if you're not sure, the easier selection is
to just throw it all in there. Now, this is something that some people are saying, and
actually almost the same number of people are saying, yeah, we'd actually do some selection
criteria in terms of which data we're going to collect. Now, this would be better from an
efficiency perspective if you know what detections you're going to engineer. And if you actually are
doing that well, I think that that's a good approach to it. I would also suggest that with
the advent of the cloud, with Sentinel and Chronicle, that I think what's going to happen
is a lot more people are going to just start throwing all the data in there because it's easy
to do. And then when they are basically spending a lot of money in order to store data that they
never use, eventually it will drive efficiency to be able to say, no, this is the detection that I
need. This is the data source that I actually need for it. And let me go ahead and decide which
data will be pushed out. For now, I don't think people have figured this out. And this probably
resonates with you. It's easier to just push it into the SIEM, pay a little bit of extra money,
not have to worry about selecting on the front side so that you can do queries afterwards.
From a budgeting perspective, there are a number of things that are out there in terms of
how people approach budgeting. Most people have a difficult time when they're working in the SOC
to understand how that works within their organization. And so the largest answer was
basically that the management takes a bunch of recommendations from the leads but ultimately
decides how they're going to allocate funding. This is the reality that all of us face. I haven't
found anybody that says, yeah, we have a limitless budget. The only people that come close to the
limitless budget are the ones that are basically immediately after a large-scale breach for the
first two years. And I'm not making this up. This is the conversations that I've had with people
consistently. For about the first two years after a large-scale breach, pretty much you can have all
the money that you want. And then after that, things start to get reined in. And the reason
for that that I've observed is that your management does not understand how the organization
effectively deploys its funding. They go and ask for stuff. And then the funding comes or it doesn't
come. Making a compelling argument on a consistent basis in order to show this is the technology that
we need to acquire, this is the staffing that we need to acquire, this is the way that this is going
to be effective at defending and providing loss prevention. Over time is how you actually
successfully win budget. But the SOC is providing an offer of loss prevention. And I think that
these words are things that you should think about how to use them in your environment.
You're not even guaranteeing loss prevention. You're providing an offer of loss prevention.
And your organization is making a decision. Is it worth it for me to spend all this money
on something that might solve some problems? Or is it better for us to just keep going and
dumping money into business investment and let all of those other things just kind of fall out
how they will? And fail a little bit, but fail as gracefully as possible. And it's not until
there's some big failures that you're, not your cyber management, but your executive management
say, yeah, yeah, yeah, we need to deal with that. The best thing that could happen to you
in terms of budgeting is to have an organization, much like the organization that you work in,
have a big breach. So you don't have to deal with the real pain of it and then take that headline
to your management and say, this is what's going on in this industry. This is how they're targeting
these people. That's basically us. And we'll be the next headline if you do not address some
of these fundamental problems. And I think that this is the key to winning budget.
Okay. And I mean, I hesitate to ask organizations to spend money when they don't need to.
And I think that that's something that we should really think about. We could fix everything
if we had limitless money. We simply don't have limitless money. And so it's the right sort of
prioritization for our budget. And this is in light of what the organization needs to do
in order to survive. Because we don't have enough staff, because we don't have enough
internal capacity, knowledge, capability, we tend to look for third parties to help us
in order to outsource some of the things that we need to do. Going back to that list of capability
that I showed earlier, this chart is a little bit confusing. So let me explain it. The way that this
chart is actually depicted is not a count, but a rank in order. So the rank that shows red is
actually the order of the sort from top to bottom. And this is the highest to least outsourced
activities and capabilities within the organization. The blue rank is whether it's
done at all. So let me just sort of move this in here. So if you look at the order of the red,
basically this is the most outsourced to the least outsourced. And the blue is the most likely
to be done to the least likely to be done. And at the top, where the red ranks are the things that
are most likely to be outsourced, there's a lot of least likely to be done type items on that list.
Pen testing, red teaming, purple teaming, the top three activities. Basically, we're very likely to
outsource them in SOCs, and we're very likely not to do it at all. So this becomes a circumstance of
is the SOC actually verifying that those detections and defenses that they're deploying
work at all? And if you're not testing it on an ongoing basis, if you're not testing it while
you're doing the detection engineering, how do you know that it works? And I'm going to tell you,
in my opinion, most SOCs don't know that it works. They don't. And it's only when either
somebody internal decides, hey, we should really do this purple teaming thing and make this
effective, that that traction becomes something where there's a drive for change.
The other thing that's very commonly outsourced, forensics and any sort of variation on forensics
and threat intelligence. And these are things that I think organizations currently are trying
to understand how to incorporate that into their pipeline within their security operations,
and they're struggling. They're struggling to be able to understand how to tactically deploy that.
So this is what the chart looks like, but it's something that's a struggle for everybody in
terms of how to decide what resources to outsource. But what they're doing is usually
outsourcing, pen testing, forensics, and threat intel.
In terms of the size of the SOC, there tends to be about 10 to 25 people.
This is blue, indicating the most common size of analysts, whereas red is more of the
administrative staff. And that, the answer was two to 10 people. So you have a few people,
three, five people kind of keeping the lights on, and then maybe 10, 15 analysts working
in order to be able to do that. I have done a bunch of different pivots on this,
I'm not going to go into it now. But what I have seen is that even really large organizations
tend to hover around that 15 to 20 staff. And again, in my experience, and looking at this
and talking to organizations, larger organizations, what they do is they have 15 staff members
internally, and then those staff members are essentially managing contractors or interfacing
with third parties that they transfer a lot of the operational work, whether you want to call it
level one, initial triage, XDR, I'm sorry, MDR for your endpoint detection response or extended
detection response. This is something that larger organizations tend to leverage outsourcing pretty
substantially. From staffing, what the staff looks like in the SOC, I asked a bit about the
hiring, like what do managers care about hiring for? And so the items that were typically
identified in information security as a general concept, the idea of threat analysis, data
analysis, and intelligence analysis were the top skills that hiring managers were looking for.
Asked about how long do employees stick around? The one to three years in the SOC was the most
common answer. Most of you, this probably resonates, especially at the level one type SOC
role. People will move for a little bit of money. And I'm actually going to address that
on the next slide in terms of what people move for and how to retain them.
But what's interesting about this is we then went and looked about, well, okay, in IT, is that normal?
Is one to three years normal? And in fact, that's about the average turnover across most of IT,
one to three years. So it's not just cybersecurity that has this notion of churn, it's IT generally.
And so in order to avoid the notion of churn, what can you do to keep people around? And this is
interesting. Career progression was substantially higher than meaningful work or money. So it's more
compelling for a person to stay in a role if they feel like they have something that they're
moving toward from a growth perspective. Money, of course, is good. I mean, everybody wants that.
But this was something, by a substantial margin, was an indication that that's how
managers were actually retaining staff. So something to think about just in terms of
how that might work. Remote work, since 2020, has been something that is quite common.
And the question usually becomes, can we securely transport the data to the staff in order to be
able to do that? Sometimes it's whether the individual is actually in a role that would
allow them to do that. So this was a breakdown of what makes it so that you can do remote work
if you're doing it. In terms of back to staffing from a hiring perspective, what technologies were
most important for hiring managers were EDR and SIN. And that's not really a surprise, but it is
something that's consistent. I have this long technology list, and I'm going to basically
talk about some of these here. I know you can't read it. But this long technology list was a
ranking of the GPA of the technology. So I asked the question, do you give it an A,
do you give it a B, do you give it a C, and so on. No technology got As in terms of what people
graded it as. The highest response was the EDR, EDR, XDR. I grouped them together in the questioning.
The next highest was email filters. And this is just a question of satisfaction. Do you like
this technology? Does it do what you want it to do? So that was at the top of the list. And down
at the bottom of the list, no surprise, artificial intelligence and machine learning. Absolute bottom
of the list. Now, this is an interesting thing. And again, I'm just my opinion in terms of
projection. Next year, AIML, I think it will be off of the bottom. And I think that over the next
couple of years, this will actually basically cycle up higher into the ranking. It was the
first time that I had it in the survey last year. It was 23. It was the first sort of debut for it.
Deception, frequency analysis, packet analysis, full PCAP have consistently been near the bottom.
This is something that people don't like, just from a perspective of that. Now again, I know that
you can't read this chart. I'm putting it up there to talk about what it is. The next thing that I
did in the chart was to be able to map the idea of how far do you get the deployment. And so we
asked the question, on the same technology set, do you have a full production deployment, a partial
production deployment? Are you in some sort of a staging but haven't finished the deployment yet?
And this complicated chart, which again, you can download the survey and look at the details of
this. But let me pull out the important components of it. This particular chart,
the tendency was that the higher ranked GPA technologies arrived at full production deployment.
Okay, so this, I cannot draw a causal relationship between it, but it is trending in the same
direction. The higher the satisfaction, the more likely that you have a full production deployment.
And so this is what your peers are saying in terms of the technology and what they're doing.
I'm going to shift a little bit in terms of what I'm talking about. I mean, I'm still going to
talk about the survey, but I'm going to talk about something momentarily. Before I do that,
I want to see if anybody has any questions on any of the charts that I've talked about so far.
Yeah, question. Yeah, actually, hold on one second. Let her give you the thing.
Hi. Do you do any trending analysis of year to year? Yes. Because I saw with hiring stuff and
turnover, it seemed like with COVID, of course, some of these numbers might change because remote
work becomes more prevalent and turnover and just the general availability of roles outside
of someone's immediate area became a lot more available. And I figured that might have a say in
reasons people are leaving. So I'm just curious if you have that.
Yeah, exactly. So two things on the trend analysis. One is yes, I do. The trend around
the question of retention, that money, I think that the first year that it was not the top was
21, if I remember correctly. But the other reason why I've been really pushing to release the
information, the de-identified responses is, and this is what I'm going to go into next,
is you can get the data and start to do some of that if you're interested.
Okay. What I release, and before I start to go into the next thing, any other questions?
Anything else? Yeah. Okay. Yeah. I got a couple of them. Because I'm going to go into the Jupyter
Lab notebook stuff, which I'll then show you how you could look at some of that too,
because there's usually questions like that from people specifically. Yeah. Please.
Hey. So for the outsourcing slide that you had on there, you had things like threat
research and threat hunting. But then on the hiring skills that people wanted was like threat
analysis and intelligence analysis. So we have a lot of outsourcing for things that people are
looking for to get, they want their staff to be intelligent on. Is it just they're not finding
these people? Yeah. That's a great question. It's actually a really interesting question in terms of
the inside of like, okay, well, we're outsourcing that a lot, but you're also saying that a skill
set that managers are looking for is threat analysis, right? So the first part of this is
that a lot of organizations actually do stuff, and I'm going to put this in here in terms of
some of the activities that are in here and try to find where the, there it is. So threat hunting,
threat research, vulnerability assessment. A lot of organizations are actually doing both
internal and external. And so, and there's some more granular questions around the threat
intelligence specifically, as an example, where it's a question of, are you doing ingestion of
IOCs or are you doing the threat intelligence origination where you're actually doing the
analysis and then sharing that? So I think that that's part of the answer to your question is that
what threat intelligence is actually takes a variety of forms. The other part of it is, I think
that threat intel is getting outsourced a lot because it's like, yeah, just go to the dark web,
pull all the stuff that might be about my company and send it to me. But then internally, we need
somebody who understands, okay, now I've got this enormous list or stick taxi or whatever form
they're getting it in, that needs to be turned into a product that becomes useful to the executives,
to the internal detection engineering monitoring and so on. So then they have a person who's taking
this sort of glut of data that's coming from their third party outsourced intelligence provider in
order to make that useful. So that's how I think that that's playing out. The other part of it is
threat analysis also becomes a risk analysis perspective. So if you can understand the threat,
then you can make it understandable to the organization on how should we respond to that.
But a great and very insightful question here. Have you had a hard time with people
self-identifying as working in the SOC? Like, for example, I know a lot of people who are
instant responders who are very firm. They're like, I do not work in the SOC. I am an instant
responder. Or people in threat intel I know also take that line. Yeah. So that's also a good
question. For me, the way that I've tried to do it is, look, it doesn't really matter if you call it a
SOC, if you call it a fusion center, if you call it a CSIRT. If you do incident response, that's fine.
And there is essentially almost a stigma associated with the notion of the monitoring
component of it. So yes, I've definitely observed that, that a lot of people push off that label
of the SOC because for some reason it's perceived as negative. And I think one of the reasons why
it's perceived as negative is there's this label and it's L1. No one wants to be construed as L1
because that's like the entry level cyber job. And there was a talk, so I've done, you know,
different presentations for years. And one of the ones that I did in 2018, it was a SOC summit that
I was doing through SANS. I'm going to get his last name wrong, but Ismael Catano, I think was
his last name, he gave a presentation at the time. He was the Verizon MSSP manager. And I'm pointing,
you know, out toward Dulles, right? So it's like, what he said was, you know, it's a really interesting
thing that the most important decision in a SOC is given to the most junior role. And usually under
tremendous time pressure, 10-minute service level objective in order to make a decision, do we need
to act or is this a false positive? And he said that what this is creating is stigma and
essentially an opportunity for missing a lot of stuff. So yes, the idea of like, do we not like
the SOC? People don't like it. And it's kind of an interesting thing. I chose this area intentionally
many years ago, because I felt like it was the biggest problem for most organizations that they
cannot figure out how to operationalize their security capability. And it persists
in the world today. So another question.
If you try to take this more to like a maturity model. So, you know, as you showed the
statistics of what going through, okay, if they're outsourcing more, it's not necessarily a bad thing.
Like the old MSSP days, they're more moving toward an MDR and XDR, next generations and all that
type of stuff, right? So is there a way to kind of gauge the journey that everybody's at the same
level, right? Yeah, that's an awesome question. And I have a bunch of other talks that I do about
maturity. But let me answer your question. There is a maturity basis that I use when I do
maturity assessments for organizations. They're Rob Van Oos out of the Netherlands.
If you look up SOC, C-M-M, S-O-C dash C-M-M, there's actually a basis for doing a maturity assessment.
And what he's done over the last several years is to try to develop a consistent assessment criteria
and I'm working with him and he has now this network of people who are actually
doing maturity assessments to provide a basis of comparison between SOCs. So this SOC survey is
kind of a different thing of like trending and what people are doing and a view of it. But
